ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.2_0: At that time the monks from the group of six were engaged in malicious talebearing between monks who were arguing.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.3_0: When they heard what they heard on the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.4_0: so that new quarrels start and existing quarrels become worse?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.5_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.6_0: “How can the monks from the group of six engage in malicious talebearing between monks who are arguing?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.7_0: How can they report to one side what they have heard on the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.8_0: and in this way start new quarrels and make existing quarrels worse?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.9_0: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.10_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.11_0: and in this way start new quarrels and make existing quarrels worse?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.14_0: “... Foolish men, how can you engage in malicious talebearing between monks who are arguing?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.15_0: How can you report to one side what you have heard on the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.15_1: How can you report to one side what you have heard on the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.16_0: so that new quarrels start and existing quarrels become worse?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.17_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.18_0: or increase the confidence of those who have it ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.19_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.20.1_0: ‘If a monk engages in malicious talebearing between monks, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.2_0: there is malicious talebearing in two ways: for one wanting to endear himself or for one aiming at division.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.3_0: One engages in malicious talebearing in ten ways: about caste, about name, about family, about occupation, about profession, about illnesses, about physical traits, about defilements, about offenses, and by name-calling.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.5_0: there are two kinds of castes: low castes and high castes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.7_0: outcasts, bamboo workers, hunters, carriage-makers, waste-removers—these are called “low castes”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.9_0: aristocrats and brahmins—these are called “high castes”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.12_0: there are two kinds of name-calling: low name-calling and high name-calling.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.14_0: “You’re a camel,” “You’re a ram,” “You’re an ox,” “You’re a donkey,” “You’re an animal,” “You’re bound for hell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.14_1: there’s no such thing as this—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.14_2: you can expect only what you have said.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.16_0: “You’re wise,” “You’re competent,” “You’re intelligent,” “You’re learned,” “You’re an expounder of the Teaching,”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.16_2: the Holy One is to be expected.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.2.1_0: If one who is fully ordained, after hearing it from another who is fully ordained, engages in malicious talebearing by saying to yet another who is fully ordained, “So-and-so says this about you, ‘He’s an outcast,’ ‘He’s a bamboo worker,’ ‘He’s a hunter,’ ‘He’s a carriage-maker,’ ‘He’s a waste-remover,’” then for every statement, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.2.1_1: When he speaks words, he commits an offense entailing confession.
